results.title: Fair go!
results.creator_credit: Tony Wright, Penny Robbins, Open Channel Productions and Peter Moon
results.brief_description: “Fair go!” is a step towards meeting the needs of young people for information about their rights as workers. Using a fresh, entertaining presentation, the program follows the experiences of school-leavers Kelly and Sam, as they fall unawares into a series of near disasters in new jobs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Wright, Penny Robbins, Open Channel Productions and Peter Moon

results.title: Globalisation 101
results.creator_credit: Alex Kelly, Kim Beamish and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Globalisation 101 looks at the impacts of corporate-lead globalisation on workers, indigenous people and the environment both locally and globally. It traces the history of transnational organisations such as the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and charts the origins of third world debt.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Kelly, Kim Beamish and SKA TV

results.title: Decent exposure
results.brief_description:
Decent Exposure evolved from the belief that art should be confronting, stimulating to those who view it. The video was an attempt to take the concept and give it concrete form. The basic plot is that art escapes en-masse from galleries and confronts people on the streets. Its left up to the cops to stop the “escapee” art from terrorising the population but to do that they have to capture the ringleader, The Expert.
The Expert is a sculpture of an art critic, a middle aged man in underpants (based on Peter Corlett’s The Connoisseur, currently in the Ian Potter Museum) struck in a judgemental pose as though he is forming a pompous opinion of an artwork.
The story was set in contemporary Melbourne (1990). Those dreary consumerists who now dominate the inner suburbs were already beginning to invade our fragile but energetic Fitzroy and St Kilda art communities. The dead hand of conservatism and bureaucratic centralisation was already being felt.
The plot ambitiously, but rather awkwardly, strove to shout to the world that, ‘the Emperor has no clothes”. In 1990 the Pyramid bank crash had just happened. The government is so on the nose electorally that party officials start moves to recruit The Expert, who has become a charismatic figure to the media. They intend him to replace the Treasurer.
Somehow I convinced journalist Jim Schembri (who bore a striking resemblance to the sculpture) that playing The Expert would be a good idea. His accepted his costume (a pair of Y front undies) with a look of trepidation.
The highlight was Jim running through the St Kilda Esplanade market, with the camera hidden 50 metres away, on a busy Sunday morning proclaiming to those he ‘confronted’ that he was a sculpture who was, ‘living, breathing art” - the great thing is that Jim was, for that moment, being accurate.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 6 [Joe Felber Multimedia Installation]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description: Presented by David McLauchlan outside the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne. David interviews multimedia artist Joe Felber and dancer/choreographer Lucy Guerin about their collaborative installation with composer Elliott Gyger entitled “25 songs on 25 lines of 25 words on Art Statement for seven voices and dance” based on Ad Reinhardt’s Black Painting and Art Statement. Following the interviews, there is a presentation of Joe Felber’s 7 minute video on the multimedia performance “25 songs on 25 lines…and dance”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: On the side of the angels
results.creator_credit: Claire Jaeger, Peter Kaufmann and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
This film presents the story of the people involved in the
movement for peace in Australia from 1900 to the present. Using rare archival film, the program reflects on the international events that concerned and influenced many people to organise together for peace and world stability. Features Ralph Gibson, founding member against war and fascism in the 30s, Stephen Murray-Smith, peace historian, Sam Goldbloom, Council for International Cooperation and Disarmament, Jim Cairns, Deputy Prime Minister with the Whitlam government, Jean McLean, radical Victorian Labour MP and Jo Camilleri, Convenor of People for Nuclear Disarmament.

results.title: Et cetera. Season 2. Episode 7 [The State Library. Melbourne Cup handover. Tumbarumba]
results.brief_description:
Northern Access Television produced this episode of the
series “Et cetera” featuring a visit to the State Library of
Victoria and an interview with Melinda Dundas - Public
Affairs Officer, who talks of the services available to
residents and tourists, and multicultural, regional and youth oriented initiatives. Interviewer Suzana Talevski
also speaks to Librarian Des Cawley. Justine Isard reports
from the Windsor Hotel where the handover of the Melbourne Cup by the Hardy Brothers to the Victorian Racing Club (VRC) is taking place. Includes footage of the cup’s production. Phillip Taylor speaks to percussion group
Tumbarumba. Presented by David McLauchlan.

results.title: My second home
results.creator_credit: Memet Gunes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Memet Gunes was one of the lucky few people in his village in Turkey to receive an education. When he migrated to Australia with his family he found a place full of possibility and opportunity.

results.title: A Chance decision
results.creator_credit: Graham Goulding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A chance decision led Graham Goulding into a teaching job in China where the banquets were endless and he and his colleagues were treated like royalty. A unique adventure that has remained with Goulding long after his return to Gippsland.
